inlineContent.text: The
data structure represents a day between January 1, Year 1,
and sometime a few thousand years in the future (right now it will go
to the year 65535 or so, but [method
] only parses up to the
year 8000 or so - just count on “a few thousand”).
is meant to
represent everyday dates, not astronomical dates or historical dates
or ISO timestamps or the like. It extrapolates the current Gregorian
calendar forward and backward in time; there is no attempt to change
the calendar to match time periods or locations.
does not store
time information; it represents a day.
The
implementation has several nice features; it is only a
64-bit struct, so storing large numbers of dates is very efficient. It
can keep both a Julian and day-month-year representation of the date,
since some calculations are much easier with one representation or the
other. A Julian representation is simply a count of days since some
fixed day in the past; for
the fixed day is January 1, 1 AD.
(“Julian” dates in the
API aren’t really Julian dates in the
technical sense; technically, Julian dates count from the start of the
Julian period, Jan 1, 4713 BC).
is simple to use. First you need a “blank” date; you can get a
dynamically allocated date from [ctor
], or you can declare an
automatic variable or array and initialize it by calling [method
A cleared date is safe; it’s safe to call [method
] and the other
mutator functions to initialize the value of a cleared date. However, a cleared date
is initially invalid, meaning that it doesn’t represent a day that exists.
It is undefined to call any of the date calculation routines on an invalid date.
If you obtain a date from a user or other unpredictable source, you should check
its validity with the [method
] predicate. [method
is also used to check for errors with [method
] and other functions
that can fail. Dates can be invalidated by calling [method
] again.
It is very important to use the API to access the
struct. Often only the
day-month-year or only the Julian representation is valid. Sometimes neither is valid.
Use the API.
GLib also features
which represents a precise time.
The
protocol exposes the methods and properties of an underlying
instance.
The default implementation of these can be found in the protocol extension below.
For a concrete class that implements these methods and properties, see
Alternatively, use
as a lighweight,
reference if you already have an instance you just want to use.

abstract.text: is a struct for calendrical calculations.
Returns the day of the year, where Jan 1 is the first day of the
year. The date must be valid.
Increments a date by some number of years.
If the date is February 29, and the destination
year is not a leap year, the date will be changed
to February 28. The date must be valid.
Returns the year of a
. The date must be valid.
Represents a precise time, with seconds and microseconds.
Simply a replacement for
. It has been deprecated
since it is not equivalent to
on 64-bit platforms
with a 64-bit
Fills in the date-related bits of a struct tm using the
value.
Initializes the non-date parts with something safe but meaningless.
Returns the day of the month. The date must be valid.
is a struct for calendrical calculations.
Sets the value of a
from a Julian day number.
Protocol for GLib types that wrap pointers.
Returns the week of the year during which this date falls, if
weeks are understood to begin on Sunday. The date must be valid.
Can return 0 if the day is before the first Sunday of the year.
Returns
if the date is on the first of a month.
The date must be valid.
is a struct for calendrical calculations.
Initializes one or more
structs to a safe but invalid
state. The cleared dates will not represent an existing date, but will
not contain garbage. Useful to init a date declared on the stack.
Validity can be tested with
Moves a date some number of days into the past.
To move by weeks, just move by weeks*7 days.
The date must be valid.

. The date must be valid.
Returns the month of the year. The date must be valid.
Generates a printed representation of the date, in a
-specific way.
Works just like the platform’s C library
function,
but only accepts date-related formats; time-related formats
give undefined results. Date must be valid. Unlike
(which uses the locale encoding), works on a UTF-8 format
string and stores a UTF-8 result.
Parses a user-inputted string
, and try to figure out what date it
represents, taking the
into account. If the
string is successfully parsed, the date will be valid after the call.
Otherwise, it will be invalid. You should check using
to see whether the parsing succeeded.

. If the resulting
day-month-year triplet is invalid, the date will be invalid.
-style comparison function for dates.
Both dates must be valid.
Returns the week of the year, where weeks are understood to start on
Monday. If the date is before the first Monday of the year, return 0.
The date must be valid.
Returns the Julian day or “serial number” of the
. The
Julian day is simply the number of days since January 1, Year 1; i.e.,
January 1, Year 1 is Julian day 1; January 2, Year 1 is Julian day 2,
etc. The date must be valid.

-specific way.

(which uses the locale encoding), works on a UTF-8 format
string and stores a UTF-8 result.

if the date is the last day of the month.
The date must be valid.
